PROVING THE SEEMINGLY IMPOSSIBLE, that ‘a+0’ is NOT equal to ‘a’ (using high school maths): Find a mistake in the following methodology (if there is one) ||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||| I am going to start by assuming that the statement a+0=a is false and by a series of operations, reach a contradiction that will justify this. ||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||| THE METHOD If a+0 = a(Whatever you do to one side of the equation, you must do to the other side) Multiplying both sides by a gives us (a+O)a = a^2Note: a^2 means ‘a squared’ ie a×a Subtract (a+0)^2 from both sides(a+O)a - (a+0)^2 = a^2 - (a+0)^2 Factorise both, the left hand side (LHS) and the right hand side (RHS) of the equationOn the LHS, (a+O) is a common factor in both terms. So we can write that outside the main brackets as: (a+0) (a- (a+0) ) On the RHS, is a difference of two squares. Factorising this will give: ( a+ (a+0) )( a- (a+0) ) Now the equation is as shown below(a+0)(a- (a+0))=(a+ (a+0))(a- (a+0)) Divide/cancel both, LHS and RHS of the above equation by ( a- (a+0) ) since this is common.This leaves us with: a+0 = a+ (a+0) Simplifying the RHS onlya+0 = 2a (CONTRADICTION) Therefore ‘a+0’ (LHS) is NOT equal to ‘a’ (RHS) PROVED (See if you can find a mistake in the shown proof and Comment on the above only) Serious mathematicians need not read further ======================= **************************** ADDENDUM : The following is just for EXTRA mental stimulation.
